qas.question: What is the main source of the alcohol in beer?
What is the process during brewing in which sugar is metabolized into alcohol?
At what concentration can yeast no longer survive in alcohol?
What could decrease alcohol content during the brewing process?
Why would more fermentable sugars be added to be beer during the brewing process?
Where do the sugars in beer come from?

plausible_answers.text: quantity of fermentable sugars in the wort and the variety of yeast used to ferment the wort

qas.question: What are primary factors that determine the amount of sugars in the final beer?

plausible_answers.text: Low temperatures and too little fermentation time

context: <b5_0>The alcohol<b5_0/> in beer comes primarily from the metabolism of <a0_0>sugars<a0_0/> that are produced during <a1_0>fermentation<a1_0/>. The <b6_0>quantity of fermentable sugars in the wort and the variety of yeast used to ferment the wort<b6_0/> are the primary factors that determine the amount of alcohol in the final beer. Additional fermentable sugars are sometimes added <a4_0>to increase alcohol content<a4_0/>, and enzymes are often added to the wort for certain styles of beer (primarily "light" beers) to convert more complex carbohydrates (starches) to fermentable sugars. <b7_0>Alcohol<b7_0/> is a by-product of yeast metabolism and is toxic to the yeast; typical brewing yeast cannot survive at alcohol concentrations <a2_0>above 12%<a2_0/> by volume. <a3_0><b8_0>Low temperatures<a3_0/> and too little fermentation time<b8_0/> decreases the effectiveness of yeasts and consequently decreases the alcohol content.
